did.abstract: Mayor of Ann Arbor, Michigan, 1978-1985. Mayoralty files and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Louis D. Belcher (donor no. 7175) in March and April 1985.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are not expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Louis D. Belcher papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Louis D. Belcher was born in Battle Creek, Michigan, on June 25, 1939. He studied industrial engineering at Kellogg Community College and in 1962 took a B.S. in business management from Eastern Michigan University. He served in the Michigan Air National Guard for 14 years (1956-1970).

Belcher dropped out of a management training course at General Motors in 1963, but one year later had become account manager for the National Cash Register Company. He left NCR in 1969, spent two years as business manager and controller for Veda, Inc., and then founded First Ann Arbor Corporation (FAAC). FAAC performs management consulting services and evaluates the design, performance, and testing methods of U.S. combat aircraft. Belcher left FAAC in 1983. He currently (1985) directs two corporations-Environmental Technology, Inc. and Midwest Microwave, Inc.-and owns Data Scan, Inc., Third Party Services, Inc., and a gun shop. He is also a partner in the real estate development firm of Shipman/Corey/Belcher, Inc.

In addition to his success as a businessman, Belcher proved to be a successful local politician as well. A Republican, he was elected to the city council from the fifth ward in 1974 and served until 1978. In 1977 he ran for mayor against incumbent Albert H. Wheeler. The election was disputed, and a special run-off in 1978 gave the office to Belcher. After winning reelection in 1979, 1981, and 1983, Belcher declined to seek a fifth term.

As mayor, Belcher stressed capital improvement projects, business development, reorganizing the city administration, repealing the "$5 marijuana law," expanding the municipal airport, and improving the Ann Arbor Transit Authority's fixed-route service. He pushed through the city's purchase of the Michigan Theater and supported the controversial Tally Hall project. The Ann Arbor News described Belcher as "politically moderate and ardently pro-business, "with a "tendency to shoot from the hip" that was "balanced by political savvy"

scopecontent.p: This collection of Belcher's papers is confined exclusively to his tenure as mayor of Ann Arbor, 1978-1985. As mayor, Belcher received copies of many of the memos and letters sent to and from the various city departments. Hence this collection represents, to some extent, the records of the city administration as a whole, not just the papers of the mayor. But there are significant gaps in the collection, and some gaps represent major concerns of Belcher's mayoralty. There is virtually no material concerning the Ann Arbor Transit Authority (AATA) or the Housing Commission. (Indeed, of the five principal city commissions, only Planning is represented here.) Most of the city offices and departments have folders in the mayor's files except the Assistant to the City Administrator for Labor Negotiations and Relations, the Data Processing office, and the Bicycle Coordinator of the Transportation Department.

The arrangement of the papers generally reflects their original order. To be sure, in most cases the original order was maintained even though cumbersome and duplicative, because the file system seemed to reflect the priorities, attitudes, and procedures of the mayor's office. When possible the contents list provides cross-references to assist the researcher in overcoming some of the complications of the arrangement. The Belcher mayoralty papers are arranged in seven series: Personal; Official Communications; City Government; Planning File; Conferences, Leagues, and Councils; Topical File; and Photographs.

Within the Personal series, the Campaign folders contain mostly clippings. However, the 1981 material includes examples of campaign literature and a concession note from Bob Faber, while the 1983 file includes an analysis of the election for the Republican party by Rae Weaver. The Correspondence file is largely composed of letters of congratulations and thanks, and of letters written by school children for class projects. But the subseries also contains letters and cards to and from officials of Ann Arbor's sister cities (Tubigen and Hikone), and some correspondence which could as easily have been filed in the general correspondence file or placed in one of the topical folders.
Official Communications is comprised of five subseries: Correspondence and Memos; "While You Were Out" message forms; Proclamations, Commendations, and Press Releases.

The largest subseries within Official Communications is that of Correspondence and Memos. Particularly noteworthy are Belcher's letters aiding the recruitment of University of Michigan basketball players and the Complaints folders. The range of the complaints is broad and includes poor hiring practices in city hall, juvenile delinquents in Gallup Park, and parking tickets. (Parking tickets seem to be the bane of the city administration's existence, and such letters will also be found in the General correspondence subseries in this series, the Transportation Department subseries of the City Government series, and the Ann Arbor Summer Festival series of the Topical File.)

did.unittitle: Letters to Prospective University of Michigan Athletes 1980-1985

odd.p: (see also Correspondence and Memos, General; also Transportation Department in City Government series)

scopecontent.p: Also worthy of mention is the While You Were Out subseries, a set of bound carbons of mostly telephone messages for the mayor. Since the forms often list the purpose of the call or a message from the caller, these books help to fill in the documentary gap normally left by business conducted over the phone.

Along with the Topical File, the City Government series forms the core of the collection. The series includes a description of the city government's functions and organization ("Your Local Government") which is useful for placing documents in their proper administrative context and for determining the likely place of topical material within the series. Also in the series are city council minutes from January 1982 through December 1983. The Budget and Finance file contains substantive memos, reports, and analyses for some years, as well as detailed printouts of expenditures and allocations. The Planning Commission file contains commission minutes, correspondence, and memos, and should be used in conjunction with the Planning File series. The City Administrator is represented in most of the series and folders in this collection, and most of the material in the file seems to be scattered in duplicates elsewhere. Reports of the disposition of city records, which should be of interest and use to researchers, comprise part of the Central Services and Purchasing file.

The two largest files are Community Development and Comprehensive Training and Employment. Both represent locally-administered federal government programs. Community Development Block Grants (CDBG) is a U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development project to fund housing rehabilitation and rent subsidies for low-income persons, street and park improvements, legal aid, and health care services. Several folders in the Topical File are cross-referenced to the Community Development series. The Labor Department's Comprehensive Employment and Training Act (CETA) is responsible for improving delivery of employment services, including counseling and training.

The Fifteenth District Court file is almost entirely made up of letters to and from Senior Judge S. J. Elden. Complaints against and praise for police officers are located in the Police Department file, along with a fiscal report and crime statistics. The Transportation Department has authority over parking enforcement, traffic engineering, and the Municipal Airport. The bulk of the material on the airport controversy will be found in the transportation department's file, but some is also located in the Planning File. The bulk of parking ticket complaints is also lodged in this file. Material on drains, sewers, and flooding will be found in the Utilities Department file.

Planning File (see also Planning Commission in City Government series)

scopecontent.p: The purpose of Planning File series is somewhat obscure, since the mayor's staff placed much related material in the Topical File. One possible purpose of the file was to highlight development projects and area plans, and probably reflects Belcher's great interest in such propositions. Along with correspondence, the series includes developers' promotional brochures, site plans, and other visual representations. There are extensive cross-references from this series to others.

scopecontent.p: Minutes, newsletters, memos, correspondence, and committee material relating to the various municipal and mayoralty organizations of which Ann Arbor and Belcher were members comprise the Conferences, Leagues, and Councils series. Belcher served on the board of directors and as president (1983-1985) of the Michigan Conference of Mayors. His actual degree of involvement in the other organizations is difficult to determine from the documents found here.

did.unittitle: Committee on Finance, Administration, and Inter-governmental Relations 1979-1984

scopecontent.p: Along with the City Government series, the Topical File series forms the core of this collection. The topical series contains correspondence and memos about the issues, places, events, and organizations represented. The file also incorporates ephemera such as brochures, programs, and meeting announcements, and more substantial documents such as minutes, reports, and financial statements.

To highlight the series accurately might run several pages, so only three examples are provided for illustrative purposes. The (Ann Arbor) Civic Theatre folder contains notices of the AACT's advisory council meetings, clippings, and proposals for fundraising and for using the old city firehouse for the theatre's headquarters. The GOP file contains agendas and minutes for Ann Arbor's party caucuses, a 1980 list of local party activists, and extensive material on the annual Concord Conferences. The conferences are workshops for Republican politicians from throughout the country, and the 1978 session featured an analysis of Belcher's campaign against Wheeler. The Halfway House folder documents the controversy surrounding a state proposal to open a correctional facility at 1700 Broadway; material includes citizen letters, the city administrator's statement at the public hearing, and a couple of letters to the mayor from the governor.

scopecontent.p: Most of the photograph folder listings are self-explanatory. The Personal photos include portraits, pictures of the mayor at ceremonial functions, giving addresses, or meeting with constituent groups, and a few "candid" shots. The Miscellaneous folder contains contact negatives and negatives of Belcher with representatives of the Jewish community and unidentified persons (probably members of the mayor's office staff).
